Explanations about Options.--ignore-existing(M):
This tells rsync to skip updating files that already exist on the destination (this
 does not ignore existing directories, or nothing would get done). See also
 --existing.
Explanations about Options.-a(M):
This is equivalent to -rlptgoD. It is a quick way of saying you want recursion and
 want to preserve almost everything (with -H being a notable omission). The only
 exception to the above equivalence is when --files-from is specified, in which case
 -r is not implied.
Explanations about Options.-d(C): I guess "rsync -d dir2/ dir1" would be next?.
Explanations about Options.-d(M):
Tell the sending side to include any directories that are encountered. Unlike
 --recursive, a directoryâ€™s contents are not copied unless the directory name
 specified is "." or ends with a trailing slash (e.g. ".", "dir/.", "dir/", etc.).
 Without this option or the --recursive option, rsync will skip all directories it
 encounters (and output a message to that effect for each one). If you specify both
 --dirs and --recursive, --recursive takes precedence.
Explanations about Options.-e(M):
This option allows you to choose an alternative remote shell program to use for
 communication between the local and remote copies of rsync. Typically, rsync is
 configured to use ssh by default, but you may prefer to use rsh on a local network.
Explanations about Options.-r(M): This tells rsync to copy directories recursively. See also --dirs (-d).
Explanations about Options.-v(M):
This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.
Explanations about Options.-z(M):
With this option, rsync compresses the file data as it is sent to the destination
 machine, which reduces the amount of data being transmitted - something that is
 useful over a slow connection.

Explanations about Options.--files-from(C): the "dst.txt" and "src.txt" files contain SHA-1 sums of the files on the two machines "comm -23 src.txt dst.txt" selects the files that either exist only on the source machine, or exist on both but are different "cut -b 43-" keeps only the filenames; this is the list of files that need to be copied "cd /some/dir" changes "CWD" to the source directory "tar cJvpf - --files-from -" makes an archive of the bunch; "--files-from -" reads the list of files to archive from "stdin", "f -" tells "tar" to write the archive to "stdout", "J" means to compress the archive with "xz", and "v" makes "tar" print the list of files it archives to "stderr" "split -b 3500MB -d" splits the archive in chunks of 3500MB (I'm assuming you have a 4GB flash memory, and the data won't fit all in a single run; you might not need to do this at all) "cat $( ls -1 x* | sort )" concatenates the "x*" files; "sort" is there to make sure it does that in the right order "cd /some/dir" changes "CWD" to the destination directory "tar xJvpf -" saves the files; "J" means decompress with "xz", "p" means restore permissions, "v" makes the operation verbose, and "f -" tells "tar" to read the archive from "stdin".
Explanations about Options.--files-from(M): Get names to extract or create from FILE.

tar xJvpf -

Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_206311: Use USB to synchronize large directory between two disconnected servers

Explanations about Options.-3(M):
Copies between two remote hosts are transferred through the local host. Without
 this option the data is copied directly between the two remote hosts. Note that
 this option disables the progress meter.
